title: Headdress (Jagún Jagún)

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of wood, iron, nails, fiber, and sacrificial materials.

artist_display:
Yòrùbá
Ekiti region, Nigeria
Coastal West Africa
description: This imposing sculptural headdress would have been worn in masquerades honoring Ogun, the Yoruba god of iron, warfare, and technology. It was also part of a shrine where offerings of yams were applied to its surface. Ogun is depicted as a warrior on horseback who carries a shield with four human heads, possibly slain enemies. The smaller figure playing a flute represents Eshu, the divine messenger and god of human destiny.
medium_display: Wood, iron, nails, fiber, and sacrificial materials
credit_line: Gift of Richard Faletti, the Faletti Family Collection
publication_history:
Jeanne Brubaker, Contrasts: Tribal Sculpture of Nigeria, exh. cat. (Fullerton, Calif.: Cultural Group Foundation of Northern Orange County, 1969), no. 16 (ill.).

Harry A. Franklin Gallery, advertisement, African Arts 3, no. 2 (1970), p. 1 (ill.)

Drewal, Henry, John Pemberton III, and Roland Abiodun.  Yoruba: Nine Centuries of African Art and Thought.  New York: Abrams for the Center for African Art, 1989 (p. 190, fig. 220; p. 194).

Los Angeles County Museum, Riders of Power in African Sculpture, exh. cat. (Los Angeles County Museum of Art, 1983), cat. 41.

Mary Nooter Roberts and Allen F. Roberts, A Sense of Wonder: African Art from the Faletti Family Collection (Phoenix: Phoenix Art Museum, 1997), pp. 25, 74; fig. 12; cat. 21A.

Sotheby’s. “The Harry A. Franklin Family Collection of African Art,” April 21, 1990, sale 6001 (lot no. 356).

Constantine Petridis et al., Speaking of Objects: African Art at the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 2020), cat. no. 41, pp. 110-111 (ill.).
exhibition_history:
Fullerton, Calif., Muckenthaler Cultural Center, Contrasts: Tribal Sculpture of Nigeria, Sept. 29-Oct. 25, 1969, cat. 16.

Los Angeles County Museum, Riders of Power in African Sculpture, Nov. 23, 1983-May 6, 1984, cat. 41.

New York, N.Y., The Center for African Art, Yoruba: Nine Centuries of African Art and Thought, Sept. 21, 1989-Jan. 7, 1990; traveled to The Art Institute of Chicago, Feb. 10-April 1, 1990; Washington, D.C., The National Museum of African Art, May 8-Aug. 26, 1990; The Cleveland Museum of Art, Sept. 26-Dec. 9, 1990; The New Orleans Museum of Art, Jan. 11-March 24, 1991; Atlanta, Ga., The High Museum of Art, April 23-June 16, 1991; The Phoenix Art Museum, Sep. 4-Oct. 6, 1991.

Phoenix Art Museum, A Sense of Wonder: African Art from the Faletti Family Collection, Dec. 13, 1997–Feb. 8, 1998, cat. 21A; traveled to Chicago, The David and Alfred Smart Museum of Art, University of Chicago, May 14–June 28, 1998; Urbana-Champaign, Krannert Art Museum and Kinkead Pavilion, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Sep. 18–Nov. 1, 1998; New York, N.Y., The Museum for African Art, Jan. 29-March 28, 1999; Davenport Museum of Art, Apr. 18–June 13, 1999; New Brunswick, N.J., Rutgers University, The Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum, Sep. 12-Nov. 24, 1999; The Boise Art Museum, Feb. 26–May 7, 2000.

Art Institute of Chicago, African Artistry: Gifts from the Faletti Family Collection, Oct. 5–May 18, 2003, Gallery 142, no. cat.

Kimbell Art Museum, Forth Worth, Texas, "The Language of Beauty in African Art", April 3-July 31, 2022.
provenance_text: Harry A. Franklin Family Collection, by 1969 [Muckenthaler Cultural Center, Fullerton, 1969, cat. no. 16]; sold, Sotheby’s, New York, N.Y., April 21, 1990 “The Harry A. Franklin Family Collection of African Art,” sale 6001, lot 356, to Richard and Barbara Faletti, Chicago, Ill.; given to the Art Institute, 2000.
